columns.text: In this problem, we have to find the **final amount** if the principle amount is compounded continuously.

When we talk about compounding, the **period** is very important. The period is signified by the use of words such as annually, semi-annually, monthly, etc. 

But if we take away the concept of this period, we arrive at what is known as **compounded continuously**. As the name suggests, the amount is getting compounded infinite times.

The formula for the **future** value of an amount that is subjected to continuous compounding is as follows: 

$$\text{Future value = Present value $\times e^{rt}$}$$

where $r$ is the interest rate,

$t$ is the time period

$e$ is the natural exponential function. It is a constant with the approximate value of $2.718$

Let us first identify the known variables:




|**Particulars** | **Value**| 
|--|--| 
|Initial deposit   | $1,275| 
Interest Rate   | 8%| 
|Time period  | 6 years|

Using the formula in step 3, we will calculate the future value. It is done below:

$$\begin{aligned} 
\text{Future Value} & = \$1,275 \times e^{0.08 \times 6}\\
& = \$1,275 \times e^{0.48}\\
& = \$1,275 \times 1.6161&&\textcolor{#4257b2}{e^{0.48}\approx1.6161} \\
& = \$2,060.5275 \\
\end{aligned}$$ 

Thus, the future value of $\$1,275$ will be approximately $\$2,060.53$
Therefore, $\$1,275$ invested today at $8\%$ **compounded continuously** for $6$ years will be worth $\$2,060.53$.
